−
Love is an emotion of intense attraction to, care for, or identification with persons, place(s) or thing(s); a desire to be close to, move and construct its object. This can include love for one's self.
+
Love is an emotion of intense attraction to, care for, or identification with persons, place(s) or thing(s); a desire to be close to, move and construct its object. This can include love for one's self. This is Mainly though used in reference for Thomas and Anna who are in deep deep love for each other. Love is controversial though and some believe that one of the parties involved in this love fest doesnt even know the other exists (anna), that it can't be true love. Thomas hasn't quite come to terms with this yet, and if he did find this out would be in deep mourning. love. Who knows though. And Thomas will more then likely stalk Anna for many many years to come.
     
However, '''love''' has several different meanings in the [[English (language)|English]] language, from something that gives a little pleasure ("I loved that meal") to something that one would die for ([[patriotism]], [[pair-bonding]]). And in contrast to the definition at the top, frequently people use the verb "love" to indicate want or desire for themselves as opposed to for another. For example: "I love ice cream," or even "I love her/him," does not refer to desiring wellness for ice cream, and it may not refer to desiring wellness for her/him, but rather to the desire for ice cream or for her/him felt by the speaker. The word also frequently indicates elevated appreciation or admiration: "I love that artist." Love can describe an intense feeling of [[affection]], an [[emotion]] or an emotional state. In ordinary use, it usually refers to interpersonal love. As an experience usually felt by a person for another person, it is commonly considered impossible to describe. Dictionaries tend to define ''love'' as deep affection or fondness.<ref>''Oxford Illustrated American Dictionary'' (1998) + ''Merriam-Webster Collegiate Dictionary'' (2000).</ref> In colloquial use, according to polled opinion, the most favoured definitions of ''love'' include the words:<ref>[http://www.humanthermodynamics.com/RP2-Love.html '04 Poll of 250 Chicagoans] – Institute of Human Thermodynamics (Chicago)</ref>
 
However, '''love''' has several different meanings in the [[English (language)|English]] language, from something that gives a little pleasure ("I loved that meal") to something that one would die for ([[patriotism]], [[pair-bonding]]). And in contrast to the definition at the top, frequently people use the verb "love" to indicate want or desire for themselves as opposed to for another. For example: "I love ice cream," or even "I love her/him," does not refer to desiring wellness for ice cream, and it may not refer to desiring wellness for her/him, but rather to the desire for ice cream or for her/him felt by the speaker. The word also frequently indicates elevated appreciation or admiration: "I love that artist." Love can describe an intense feeling of [[affection]], an [[emotion]] or an emotional state. In ordinary use, it usually refers to interpersonal love. As an experience usually felt by a person for another person, it is commonly considered impossible to describe.
